DANCE 35.title: History and Appreciation of World Dance
DANCE 35.description: Introduction to dance as cultural and social expression in a variety of cultures. Forms covered include Flamenco, Ballet in Global Perspective, Afro-Caribbean, South Asian, and Latin/x forms of dance.

DANCE 36.title: History of Modern Dance
DANCE 36.description: Historical development of modern dance in the United Sates and Europe in the twentieth century. Emphasis on visionary, feminist, and radical aspects of the form.

DANCE 40.title: Summer Ballet
DANCE 40.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 18 units.

DANCE 41.title: Summer Modern Dance
DANCE 41.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 18 units.

DANCE 42A.title: Beginning Ballet
DANCE 42A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
DANCE 42A.description: Introduction to basic elements of ballet.

DANCE 42B.title: Beginning Ballet
DANCE 42B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
DANCE 42B.description: Beginning ballet. Introduction to basic elements of ballet.

DANCE 42C.title: Beginning Ballet
DANCE 42C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
DANCE 42C.description: Introduction to basic elements of ballet.

DANCE 42D.title: Continuing Ballet
DANCE 42D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 42D.description: Further study of basic elements of ballet.

DANCE 42E.title: Continuing Ballet
DANCE 42E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 42E.description: Further study of basic elements of ballet.

DANCE 42F.title: Continuing Ballet
DANCE 42F.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 42F.description: Further study of basic elements of ballet.

DANCE 43A.title: Beginning Street Dance Forms
DANCE 43A.description: Introduction to the various forms of street dance including Hip Hop and  Isolations.

DANCE 43B.title: Beginning Street Dance Forms
DANCE 43B.description: Introduction to the various forms of street dance including House Dance, Whacking, and Punking.

DANCE 43C.title: Beginning Street Dance Forms
DANCE 43C.description: Introduction to the various forms of street dance, including Voguing,  Freestyle, Popping, and Locking.

DANCE 44A.title: Beginning Modern Dance
DANCE 44A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units each.
DANCE 44A.description: Introduction to basic elements of modern dance.

DANCE 44B.title: Beginning Modern Dance
DANCE 44B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units each.
DANCE 44B.description: Introduction to basic elements of modern dance.

DANCE 44C.title: Beginning Modern Dance
DANCE 44C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units each.
DANCE 44C.description: Inroduction to basic elements of modern dance.

DANCE 44D.title: Continuing Modern Dance
DANCE 44D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 44D.description: Further study of basic elements of modern dance.

DANCE 44E.title: Continuing Modern Dance
DANCE 44E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 44E.description: Further study of basic elements of modern dance.

DANCE 44F.title: Continuing Modern Dance
DANCE 44F.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 44F.description: Further study of basic elements of modern dance.

DANCE 45.title: History and Appreciation of Dance
DANCE 45.description: Introduction to history and appreciation of dance. Explores dance from a wide cross-cultural perspective of cultural mutuality and diversity, established traditions, and the power of dance to bring about social change, activism and justice.

DANCE 46.title: Introduction to Social Dance: History and Practice
DANCE 46.description: An introductory level survey of Social Dance. Studio-  based physical practice will be complimented by a survey of the history, theory and/or literature of Social Dance. A beginning level elective dance course, Intro to Social Dance focuses on forms developing in Europe, North and South America, as well as their migration and development across borders. Course work is grounded in the physical study of multiple styles alongside outside classwork comprised of readings, viewings and collaborative group projects.

DANCE 47A.title: Ballet I
DANCE 47A.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 47A.description: Analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements of the ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 47B.title: Ballet I
DANCE 47B.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 47B.description: Analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements of the ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 47C.title: Ballet I
DANCE 47C.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 47C.description: Analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements of the ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 47D.title: Ballet II
DANCE 47D.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 47D.description: Further analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 47E.title: Ballet II
DANCE 47E.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 47E.description: Further analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 47F.title: Ballet II
DANCE 47F.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 47F.description: Further analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 50.title: Fundamentals of Choreography
DANCE 50.description: A study of the basic elements pertaining to the craft of choreography. Emphasis on exploration of movement variation, breath rhythm, the development of dance phrases, and the use of stage space. For dance majors.

DANCE 51.title: Improvisation
DANCE 51.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 51.description: The fundamental exploration of movement potential with particular focus on the individual and group dynamics.

DANCE 53.title: Contact Improvisation
DANCE 53.description: Lower division studio course in the fundamentals of Contact Improvisation (as developed by Steve Praxton, and his contemporaries.)  Exploring the egalitarian effort of shared weight and mutual support. Contact Improvisation serves as a fundamental step in a dance student's partnering training, and informs a deeper sense of weight and sentimentality in individual dance technique.
DANCE 53.recommended_prep: Beginner to Intermediate level Modern Technique.

DANCE 56A.title: Modern Dance I
DANCE 56A.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 56A.description: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement as an expressive medium. For dance majors.

DANCE 56B.title: Modern Dance I
DANCE 56B.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 56B.description: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement as an expressive medium. For dance majors.

DANCE 56C.title: Modern Dance I
DANCE 56C.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 56C.description: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement as an expressive medium. For dance majors.

DANCE 56D.title: Modern Dance II
DANCE 56D.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 56D.description: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement as an expressive medium at the intermediate level. For dance majors.

DANCE 56E.title: Modern Dance II
DANCE 56E.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 56E.description: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement as an expressive medium at the intermediate level. For dance majors.

DANCE 56F.title: Modern Dance II
DANCE 56F.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be   repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by   audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 56F.description: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement as an  expressive medium at the intermediate level. For dance majors.

DANCE 60.title: Summer Jazz Dance
DANCE 60.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 18 units.

DANCE 82AR.title: Special Topics: Physical Practice - Aerial Dance

DANCE 82JZ.title: Special Topics, Physical Practice: Jazz Technique

DANCE 82AAZZ.title: Special Topics: Physical Practice
DANCE 82AAZZ.comments:
Open to non-majors.
Repeat Comments: DANCE 82 may be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
DANCE 82AAZZ.description: A Super Course designed to house various forms of physical practice/technique not currently represented in the curriculum. Topics may include: somatic forms such as Alexander Technique, Yoga, Pilates: non-western dance forms such as West African, Flamenco, Kathak, Bhara Natyam, Korean Dance, Cambodian Dance, etc.; percussive forms such as Tap, Hoofing, or Clogging; or many other forms that may be the expertise of faculty, guest artists, visiting lecturers/professors, or graduate students.

DANCE 94.title: Group Studies for Lower-Division Dance Students
DANCE 94.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, but only 8 units may  be applied toward the major.
DANCE 94.description: Group studies in selected areas of emphasis.

DANCE 99.title: Independent Study in Dance
DANCE 99.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and department; completion of lower-division dance
DANCE 99.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA and are limited to 5 units per    quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses   combined.
DANCE 99.description: Independent study in dance. Projects in pedagogy, choreography or dance  research.

DANCE 120.title: Aesthetics of Performance: New Visions in Contemporary Dance and Theater
DANCE 120.description: An exploration of diversity, meaning and influence in the art-making process. This course aims to develop an articulate, critical facility with a sharp aesthetic eye. Students will view, discuss, and write about the art work of contemporary and historically significant dance, theater, and visual artists with a focus on the experimental and avant-garde.

DANCE 142M.title: Masculinities In/As Performance
DANCE 142M.comments:
Open to non-majors.
Repeat Comments: Course cannot be repeated for additional units of credit.
DANCE 142M.description: Upper division seminar exploring the intersection of multiple masculinities IN performance (dance, theater, performance art, film/TV, internet platforms, and more), and AS performance.  Topics include maleness/masculinity as a social construct, considerations of masculinity in adolescent development and pedagogy, implications of race and class: marginalized masculinities, female masculinity, trans-masculinity, and more. These lenses are then employed to consider how masculinity forms identity and frames representation in various performative platforms.

DANCE 143A.title: Street Dance Forms
DANCE 143A.description: Focuses on the various forms of street dance: Hip Hop, House Dance,  Popping, Locking, Whacking, Punking, Voguing, and Freestyle. Students  learn the physical lexicon of the various styles, and are immersed in  the cultural aspects of the forms, contextualizing the dances both   historically and socially. With a strong focus on accurately embodying the essence of each style, the class breaks down the initiation of   motion and pathways of energy that result in these unique and    specialized modes.

DANCE 145B.title: Critical Topics in Dance History: Ballet in Global Perspective
DANCE 145B.description: Upper division seminar that studies the historical relationship of ballet dancing to the body politic from the global economies of Italian city-states through Louis XIV's use of ballet as weapon of state to revolutionary Russia whose exiled artists dispersed contemporary ballet worldwide.

DANCE 145C.title: Dancing the Diaspora: Dances of the Afro-Caribbean and American Worlds
DANCE 145C.description: Upper division seminar that traces a genealogy of dance and choreographic practice from West Africa throughout the Afro-  Caribbean during the transatlantic slave trade and into the Southern, Midwestern and Northeastern states of the U.S. We will study the Africanist presence in the body from Brazil to Cuba to New Orleans to New York City.

DANCE 145D.title: George Balanchine and the New York City Ballet, 1904-  Present
DANCE 145D.description: Upper-division seminar that focuses on the exiled Russian architect of American ballet George Balanchine and his  appropriation and incorporation of Afro-American jazz/tap into the corporeal language of classical ballet.

DANCE 145E.description: Upper division seminar that considers the history of modernism in dance, theater, music and art from Russia on the eve of its Bolshevik Revolution to America. We study the revolutionary Moscow Art Theater, Isadora Duncan's influence on the Ballets Russes and the feminist protest theater of Martha Graham, Helen Tamiris, Charles Weidman and Anna Sokolow.

DANCE 145G.title: Race, Immigration, and Contemporary American Dance
DANCE 145G.description: Race, Ballet, and Contemporary American Dance is a quarter-long, upper division Dance Studies course that examines how racism has shaped artistic practice and perception of the dancing body in both classical and contemporary dance.

DANCE 145H.title: Flamenco and the Afro-Roma Presence in Spanish History
DANCE 145H.description: Dance history and performance traces the African and Roma-Gypsy origins of Flamenco in its artistic, ethno-religious and political formation. Together, we trace the cultural origins of Flamenco: ethnic, religious, cultural, and geographic. Flamenco is a transhistorical form of guitar (tocque), spoken word or rapped song (cante), and dance (baile) that dates to the Hispano-Arab, African, and Roma (Gypsy presence in 'Al Andalus, southern Spain. A transatlantic form of performance art performed by artists worldwide, Flamenco is the visual, musical, and corporeal embodiment of exile. An expression of resistance to homelessness and persecution, Flamenco's texture, look, and feel are reminders of the diasporic wandering of the Roma people.

DANCE 145W.description: Upper division seminar that traces a history of Postmodern,      site-specific dance in California and New York and focuses specifically  on 3 seminal American artists: Anna Halprin, Simone Forti and Yvonne   Rainer.

DANCE 147A.title: Ballet III
DANCE 147A.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 147A.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors. Open to non majors by audition.

DANCE 147B.title: Ballet III
DANCE 147B.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 147B.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 147C.title: Ballet III
DANCE 147C.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 147C.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors.

DANCE 147D.title: Ballet IV
DANCE 147D.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units each, but only 8 units each may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 147D.description: Further analysis and exploration of the technical and expressive elements of ballet.

DANCE 147E.title: Ballet IV
DANCE 147E.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units each. Open to non majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 147E.description: Further analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium.

DANCE 147F.title: Ballet IV
DANCE 147F.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units each. Open to non majors by audition; first day of class serves as audition.
DANCE 147F.description: Further analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium.

DANCE 147S.title: Ballet III
DANCE 147S.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition; first class serves as audition.
DANCE 147S.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical and expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors. Open to non majors by audition.

DANCE 147PA.title: Ballet: Pointe
DANCE 147PA.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit in combination with Dance 147P to a maximum of 10 units each, but only 6 units each may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition.
DANCE 147PA.description: Basic pointe work, including barre and center practice. For dance majors.

DANCE 147PB.title: Ballet: Pointe
DANCE 147PB.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit in combination with Dance 147P to a maximum of 10 units each, but only 6 units each may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition.
DANCE 147PB.description: Basic pointe work, including barre and center practice. For dance majors.

DANCE 147PC.title: Ballet: Pointe
DANCE 147PC.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit in combination with Dance 147P to a maximum of 10 units each, but only 6 units each may be applied toward the major. Open to non majors by audition.
DANCE 147PC.description: Basic pointe work, including barre and center practice. For dance majors.

DANCE 149.title: Dance Workshop
DANCE 149.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
DANCE 149.description: Projects in performance, production, choreography, and directing.

DANCE 151A.title: Choreography
DANCE 151A.description: Analysis of the elements of choreographic form; styles and trends; experience in development of dance studies; theory and technique of advanced choreography. Part A focuses on formal devices and developmental tools of dance composition, and introduces duet form.

DANCE 151B.title: Choreography
DANCE 151B.description: Analysis of the elements of choreographic form; styles and trends; experience in development of dance studies; theory and technique of advanced group choreography. Part B taps more broadly into the methods and theories behind dance composition and movement invention and interrogates multiple points of entry into the making process.  Self-solo, duet and trio form is explored.

DANCE 151C.title: Choreography
DANCE 151C.description: Analysis of the elements of choreographic form; styles and trends; experience in development of dance studies; theory and technique of advanced group choreography.

DANCE 151E.title: Choreography for the Theatre
DANCE 151E.description: The study of important dance routines of the American musical theatre from 1789 to present, with opportunity for perfomance.

DANCE 151DA.title: Digital Editing for Dance
DANCE 151DA.description: A video skill-building course that introduces students to non-  linear editing software and video camera operation.  Drawing upon choreographic principles, students will create short film projects expanding their compositional proficiency and their technical knowledge of video editing tools.

DANCE 151DB.title: Digital Dance Portfolio
DANCE 151DB.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
DANCE 151DB.description: Focus on the creation of a video portfolio of choreographic work.  Building on technical editing skills with an  introduction to formatting options for web-ready, DVD-ready and large screen-ready video, and compositional techniques in editing theatrical dance works.

DANCE 151DC.title: Dance Videography
DANCE 151DC.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
DANCE 151DC.description: Focus on the creation of a video portfolio of choreographic work. Building on technical editing skills with an introduction to formatting options for web-ready, DVD-ready and large screen-ready video, and compositional techniques in editing theatrical dance works.

DANCE 156A.title: Modern Dance III
DANCE 156A.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class will serve as audition.
DANCE 156A.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium. For dance majors. Open to non majors by audition.

DANCE 156B.title: Modern Dance III
DANCE 156B.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class will serve as audition.
DANCE 156B.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium. For dance majors.

DANCE 156C.title: Modern Dance III
DANCE 156C.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class will serve as audition.
DANCE 156C.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium. For dance majors.

DANCE 156D.title: Modern Dance IV
DANCE 156D.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class will serve as audition.
DANCE 156D.description: Further analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium.

DANCE 156E.title: Modern Dance IV
DANCE 156E.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to maximum of 8 units. Open to non-majors by audition; first day of class will serve as audition.
DANCE 156E.description: Further analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium.

DANCE 156F.title: Modern Dance IV
DANCE 156F.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units each. Open to non majors by audition; first day of class will serve as audition.
DANCE 156F.description: Further analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an expressive medium.

DANCE 156S.title: Advanced Modern Dance
DANCE 156S.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
DANCE 156S.description: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of dance as an  expressive medium.

DANCE 158.title: Pedagogy II
DANCE 158.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units but only 8 units may count toward major.
DANCE 158.description: Further analysis of the theory and practice of teaching dance, including function and esthetics in the development of movement vocabulary,    application of anatomy, kinetics and musicality. Includes practical    experience teaching dance classes.

DANCE 158A.title: Teaching Dance in Community: Fundamentals of Engaging the At-Risk Youth  Artist
DANCE 158A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
DANCE 158A.description: Upper-division, hands-on course that teaches undergraduate students how  to teach dance, choreography, and digital media to at-risk youth in  fragile economic communities. Students will be mentored by professor and master artists, develop syllabi and teach a dance curriculum.

DANCE 158B.title: Fundamentals of Dance Pedagogy
DANCE 158B.description: Upper division course examining philosophical and practical methodologies in teaching dance for children and adults, while focusing on multicultural awareness, academic study, Laban Movement Analysis, neuroscience, and classroom management. The integration of theory and practice, critical thinking skills, communication, collaboration and creativity are all emphasized.

DANCE 158C.title: Classical Ballet Pedagogy: The Art of Teaching Ballet Technique, Pointe, Male Technique, and Pas de Deux
DANCE 158C.description: Upper Division studio course in classical ballet instruction. The fundamentals of teaching ballet  technique from Vaganova, Balanchine, and the ABT Curriculum. Students learn how to structure a ballet class, understand alignment corrections, ballet vocabulary, step progression, and combination development for optimal dancer development. The course also covers pointe work, male technique, and partnering. The course stresses how to use positivity, encouragement, psychology, and emphasize using correct vocabulary when teaching to avoid physically handling students.

DANCE 163.title: Advanced Improvisation
DANCE 163.comments: May be repeated once for credit for a maximum of 4 units. Only two units may be applied for credit in the major.
DANCE 163.description: An Advanced-level studio course focusing on various approaches and applications of dance improvisation. Topics covered include solo and group improvisation, score building and utilization, contact improvisation (CI), and improvisation for performance and site-specific  work. Students are assigned readings and viewings to ground their work in the classroom within past and current theory and improvisational practices.
DANCE 163.recommended_prep: Dance 50, Dance 51, Dance 56A-F or equivalent experience.

DANCE 164.title: Integrated Dance Partnering
DANCE 164.description: An Upper Division, intermediate/advanced study of the skills, mechanics and intersection of multiple partnering dance forms. Integrated Partnering will draw from contact improvisation, ballet and contemporary partnering in order to develop a broad understanding, and adaptable command of partnering.  Beyond foundational mechanics, conditioning and safe practices, the course delves into selected repertory phrase work-and partnered work in collaborative, compositional, and improvisational capacities; supporting the practical application of skills in a professional rehearsal context.

DANCE 165.title: Embodied Anatomy
DANCE 165.description: For dancers and individuals interested in studying human anatomy from a dancer's perspective, including scientific information, experiential practice, and a focus on both the body's physical structure and its kinetic possibilities. Brings awareness to how we synthesize time and space in order to move rhythmically, create coherent shapes, locomote through space and organize complex coordination of multiple systems within the body. Anatomical awareness helps with injury prevention and offers one a more meaningful relationship to their human form.

DANCE 166.title: DANCE DRAMATURGY: THEORY IN PRACTICE
DANCE 166.prereq_description: DA 151A, DA 151B  No pre-requisites for Graduate Students, instructor approval needed for non-Theater/Dance graduate students
DANCE 166.description: A seminar/studio course centered on the theory and practice of new work dramaturgy, specifically in the areas of Dance, and Devised Dance/Physical Theater. Studying and practicing contemporary approaches to dramaturgy in American contexts, we consider its varied applications and locate its development from origins in the European Theater. Two-thirds of course activity is fulfilled in a seminar format--with discussions, readings and viewings--and one-third covers practical dramaturgical work on a chosen project during the quarter.

DANCE 167A.title: Senior Solo Experimental Performance: Workshop in Creative Practice
DANCE 167A.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter. Course cannot be repeated for additional units.
DANCE 167A.description: Project development techniques, exploring modes of creative expression through various art disciplines and live performance techniques. Students engage in weekly workshops and discussions to build a tool kit for innovative dance creation.

DANCE 167B.title: Senior Solo Experimental Performance: Multimedia Project Development
DANCE 167B.comments: Quarters usually offered: Spring. Course cannot be repeated for additional units.
DANCE 167B.description: Individually researched performance projects. Engaging with dance, music, theater, object-based storytelling, video projection, visual art and world building techniques. Students create a unique one-person show/presentation to be shared in a live public performance ant the end of the quarter. Based primarily in one on one mentor-ship through the process of devising and refining the final project.

DANCE 171.title: Music for Dance: Listening Based Survey of Contemporary Aesthetics
DANCE 171.description: Overview of form, structure, and tonality in western music, including global and historical influences. Examination of styles of music composition and performance, related to dance and choreography.

DANCE 182AAZZ.title: Special Topics: Physical Practice
DANCE 182AAZZ.comments:
Designed for majors.
Repeat Comments: DANCE 182 may be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
DANCE 182AAZZ.description: A Super Course designed to house various forms of physical practice/technique not currently represented in the curriculum.  Topics could include: somatic forms such as Alexander Technique, Yoga, Pilates: non-western dance forms such as West African, Flamenco, Kathak, Bharathanatyam, Korean Dance, Cambodian Dance, etc.: percussive forms such as Tap, Hoofing, or Clogging; or many other forms that may be the expertise of faculty, guest artists, visiting lecturers/professors, or graduate students.

DANCE 186.title: Dance Production
DANCE 186.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
DANCE 186.description: Exploration of the process of collaboration between dance choreographers and theatre designers in the development of designs for dance productions. Final project will be a public performance of the choreographers' and  designers' work.

DANCE 189.title: Elements of Performing
DANCE 189.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
DANCE 189.description: The study of stage technique for the development of alert, responsive, and dynamic performers. Individual coaching in the elements of     performing such as projection, timing, and pre-  performance preparation.

DANCE 190.title: UCSB Dance Company
DANCE 190.comments: May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 16 units, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major.
DANCE 190.description: Selected students work as dancers in the UCSB Dance Company, studying and analyzing choreography and performance. The company performs locally and/or on tour. Students experience the integral workings of a company.

DANCE 191.title: Senior Project
DANCE 191.description: Choreographic or performance project produced as the culminating presentation for the B.F.A. degree. Course includes detailed documentation of the procedure followed during the creation of the final project, and results in a written and visual document following a closely crafted prompt.

DANCE 193H.title: Senior Honors Project
DANCE 193H.comments: This course is for students who will complete their projects in one    quarter. A final grade will be assigned upon completion. Students must   have a 3.0 university grade-point average; 3.4 departmental grade-point  average, unless exempt by petition; faculty nomination.
DANCE 193H.description: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic research or creative activity, supervised by a faculty advisor. Students    successfully completing the project, as evaluated by a three-person    committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.

DANCE 193HA.title: Senior Honors Project
DANCE 193HA.comments: Students must have a 3.0 university grade-point average; 3.4 departmental grade-point average, unless exempt by petition; faculty nomination. A three quarter "in-progress" course with grades assigned upon completion of Dance 193HC.
DANCE 193HA.description: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic research or creative activity, supervised by a faculty advisor. Students successfully completing the project, as evaluated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major. Students must ha 3.0 university grade-point average; 3.4 departmental grade-point average, unless exempt by petition; faculty nomination.

DANCE 193HB.title: Senior Honors Project

DANCE 193HC.title: Senior Honors Project
DANCE 193HC.comments: Students must have a 3.0 university grade-point average; 3.4 departmental  grade-point average, unless exempt by petition; faculty nomination. A  three quarter "in-progress" course with grades assigned upon completion of Dance 193HC.

DANCE 194.title: Group Studies in Dance
DANCE 194.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
DANCE 194.description: Group projects in selected areas of emphasis.

DANCE 195.title: SBDT Apprentice/Mentor Program
DANCE 195.description: Prepares students for professional work in the field of dance. Apprentices will join with professional dancers in UC Santa Barbara?s resident professional dance company, Santa Barbara Dance Theater, to rehearse choreographic works, with the possibility of performing in studio showings, repertory previews and the company?s concerts on and off campus. These experiences are expected to raise each apprentice?s awareness of collaborative methods and professional standards of performance artistry.  The artistic director of Santa Barbara Dance Theater will be designated as the instructor of record, with mentoring and coordinating assistance from one or more company members.

DANCE 199.title: Independent Study in Dance
DANCE 199.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and department; upper-division standing; completion  of 2 upper-division courses in Dance.
DANCE 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quaters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all       98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
DANCE 199.description: Independent study in dance. Projects in choreography or dance research.

DANCE 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Dance
DANCE 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Dance;  consent of instructor and department.
DANCE 199RA.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are  limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all       98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
DANCE 199RA.description: Independent research assistance in dance. Supervised assistance in faculty research project.
